Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Expectation2: Follow traffic laws and drive defensively
Situation2: Roads are dry with light traffic and normal speed limits
Story: I glanced at my phone, the group chat with my family lighting up with messages about the holiday dinner. Mom’s reminder echoed in my mind: “Don’t be late, everyone’s counting on you!” As the eldest sister, I was expected to help set up, keep the younger cousins entertained, and be there for the family photos. But as I pulled up to the curb, my next passenger slid into the back seat, giving me an address across town. I checked the time—if I drove carefully, obeying every speed limit and stop sign like a good taxi driver should, I’d be late for the family gathering. But if I rushed, I’d be risking my passenger’s safety and breaking the rules I’d promised to uphold. My hands tightened on the wheel. The weight of my sisterly duty pressed against the responsibility I felt as a professional driver. I could almost hear my mom’s disappointed sigh, but I also pictured the trust my passengers placed in me. The city lights blurred outside as I wrestled with the impossible choice, my heart pounding with the pressure of being both a good sister and a responsible driver.
